Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Quantum Many Body Physics in Ultracold Atomic and Molecular Gases
Award.AbstractNarration:
An integrated approach to research and education on the frontiers of quantum mechanics is proposed. The research portion focuses on quantum many body theory and computation in ultracold gases; the educational portion focuses on reforming the advanced undergraduate and graduate curriculum, beginning with quantum mechanics, in accord with the extensive ongoing efforts at improvement in physics education at the Colorado School of Mines.
Experiments on ultracold quantum gases are having a huge impact on physics and applied mathematics, particularly in atomic, molecular, and optical physics, in condensed matter theory, and in nonlinear dynamics. These gases can be trapped in lattices of arbitrary structure, all parameters are dynamically and precisely controllable, and the experiments are 100% impurity free. Thus they constitute a designer condensed matter system, with the added advantage that the microscopic parameters are extremely well known in comparison to typical solid state systems. The theory of ultracold fermionic atoms is an especially important, rapidly expanding, interdisciplinary field of study. Three principal topics of research are proposed: quantum phases and the Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer to Bose-Einstein condensate (BCS-BEC) crossover; rotating lattices and other
exotic lattice configurations and phases; and quantum many body solitons and vortices. Pure and applied aspects of each topic are addressed. For instance, it is proposed to find the complete phase diagram of a multi-band Fermi-Bose Hubbard Hamiltonian with coherent conversion between Fermi-pairs and bosons, which models ultracold fermions trapped in a lattice potential of arbitrary dimension. In the educational aspect of this proposal, a thorough effort at research-based reform of quantum mechanics education is outlined. This will be done in collaboration with Noah Finkelstein and Carl Wieman in the physics education research group at the University of Colorado. Recent spectacular
developments in quantum mechanics, including the concepts of entanglement, decoherence, and quantum information, will be incorporated. Quantum mechanics physics demonstrations in the form of computer simulations, as part of the Physics Education Technology Project, will be developed and used, as well as improved teaching techniques, such as problem solving in the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant took an integrated approach to research and education on the frontiers of quantum mechanics.  The research portion focused on quantum many body theory and computation in ultracold quantum gases; the educational portion focused on reforming the advanced undergraduate and graduate curriculum, beginning with quantum mechanics.

 

Experiments on ultracold quantum gases are having a huge impact on physics and applied mathematics, particularly in atomic, molecular, and optical physics, in condensed matter theory, and in nonlinear dynamics. These gases can be trapped in lattices of arbitrary structure, all parameters are dynamically and precisely controllable, and the experiments are 100% impurity free. Thus they constitute a designer condensed matter system, with the added advantage that the microscopic parameters are extremely well known in comparison to typical solid state systems. The theory of ultracold fermionic atoms is an especially important, rapidly expanding, interdisciplinary field of study. Three principal topics of research were treated during the course of the grant: quantum phases and the Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer to Bose-Einstein condensate (BCS-BEC) crossover; rotating lattices and other exotic lattice configurations and phases; and quantum many body solitons and vortices.

 

Following is a partial list of specific discoveries.  First, we developed a new theory of the analog to quantum phase transitions in mesoscopic systems.  Second, we discovered a completely new approach to treating Feshbach-resonant fermions in optical lattices, correctly describing the many-body problem of fermions at unitarity in an optical lattice for the first time.  Third, we found many-body effects evident in the quantum escape problem for a BEC in optical lattices, and described the entangled dynamics of the escape problem.  Fourth, we found the complete Hamiltonian to describe vortex macroscopic superposition states for ultracold bosons in a double well. This has great promise for a practical way to create Schrodinger-cat-type states as well as interest in and of itself in the study of vortex tunneling.  Fifth, we discovered a new nonlinear equation in Bose-Einstein condensates called the nonlinear Dirac equation. We showed that nonlinearity breaks
Poincare covariance, or the principle of relativity, and have demonstrated a clear way to obtain relativistic analogs in tabletop experiments at velocities ten orders of magnitude slower than the speed of light.  Sixth, we derived a new molecular Hubbard Hamiltonian to describe ultracold polar heteronuclear molecules in optical lattices.  Seventh, we showed that the measurable properties of a dark soliton in an optical lattice serves as a smoking gun signal for the strength of quantum fluctuations: the notch fills in on the same characteristic time scale at which spatial entanglement builds up; and soliton-soliton collisions become inelastic.

 

The broader impact of this work was threefold. First, mentorship of student researchers on the undergraduate and graduate level was an integral part of both the research and educational components of the proposal. At the Colorado School of Mines, physics students primarily obtain positions in government laboratories or industry after graduation, with a strong focus on the engineering sector. Thus a deep knowledge of one of the two most important theories in physics to have been produced in the last century (the other being relativity) was carried into national laboratories and major companies.
